div.head: TO THE right VVorshipfull, Sir William Skipwith knight, and one of his Maiesties Iustices of the peace in the county of Leicester, the rich blessings of God, to his comfort in this life, and eternall saluation in the life to come.
div.p:
THese two sermons (right worshipfull) were penned by me, at the instance of a neere friend, presently after they were preached, but (I protest) not with a purpose euer to haue had them put foorth in print.
Notwithstanding, the partie that hath them in possession, is growen so resolute, that they shall to the presse, (how vnpollished soeuer) that I am compelled to yeelde thereto, though against my will, because I see no remedy. Onely thus much, I haue obtained, that they may go foorth vnder your protection, to whom next vnder God, I am beholding, and from whom, together with your deceased father, I haue receiued mayntenance, and vnder whom I haue spent my time by labouring in the Lords vineyard now full twenty and seuen yeeres: Perswading my selfe, that as you loue the Word, and the teachers
thereof, so you will vouchsafe to accept of this my litle worke, though simple, yet agreeable to the sincere word of God, not so much respecting the worke-man far vnworthy to vndergo such a waight, as in regard of him who first opened my mouth, and made me able to deliuer it to his people. And the rather for that, as the Euangelist Saint Luke did of loue, (being inspired therunto by the holy Ghost) dedicate his booke to the most noble Theophilus: so I, though no way by the abundance of Gods Spirit so enabled, yet according to that piece of a Talent giuen me of the Lord, haue out of that dutifull loue I alwayes
bare towards you, presumed to commend vnto you these abortiue first fruits of my publique abours by writing, presented like the widowes mite into the treasury of your fauourable tuition, to be protected from the poyson of Momus and Zoilus, and others of that viperous brood. And thus I humbly take my leaue, committing you to him who neuer leaueth his, &c.

closer.signed: Your worships to be commanded in the Lord. William Ward.

The name of God is diuersly taken Exod.

Abraham builded an Altar, and called vppon the name of the Lord. Sometime for the name of God Iehouah, and so I take it in this place. Seuit. 24. 11. This glorious and fearefull name of God is many waies prophaned, and vnreuerently abused amongst the wicked, whereby they draw downe the plagues and iudgements of God vppon themselues, but most vsually,

list.item: 1 In their idle and ordinary talke.

div.p:
For the first, we ought not so much as thinke of, much lesse speake of that glorious name of God, but with feare and trembling. Leuit. 19. Thou shalt not defile the name of thy God, I am the Lorde, Sap. 1. 1. Thincke reuerently of the Lorde,
and seeke him in simplicitie of heart. And in this chapter Deut. 28. 58. vnto all the curses, iudgements and plagues which the Lorde threateneth, as the curse at home, the curse abroad, the curse of sicknesse, of madnesse, of famine, oppression, captiuitie, &c. In the end, h√©e addeth this as the chiefest: These and many moe plagues the Lord will lay vpon thee, if thou doe not feare the glorious and fearefull name of the Lord, Psal. 8. O Lord our God howe excellent is thy name in all the world! The Aben Ezra. Egyptians had a custome to sweare by the head of their king, which othe whosoeuer did not performe, might not b√©e red√©emed from death by any ransome, bicause he despised the king: how much more then ought not w√©e to name, or so much as once thinke of the name of our glorious God, but with feare and reuerence? Exodus 20. Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vaine. As w√©e must take h√©ede of the errour of the Anabaptists, so we must not take Gods holy name in vaine, but vse it reuerently, with feare and trembling. But it is an ordinary thing with most men, to haue the Name of God continually in theyr
mouths, when as (for the most part) they neuer thinke of him while they speake of him. How vsuall is it to say one to another, God sp√©ede you, God be with you, God helpe you, God send you health, &c. when they haue no such thing in thought? Take heed then how at any time thou speakest of God, except thy tongue‚ñ™ and heart goe together with feare and reuerence, For as Ecclus. 23. A seruant which is often punished cannot be without some scarre, so hee that sweare: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and nameth God continually shall not bee faultlesse. And let all good children say with Dauid. Psalme 72. 18. Blessed bee the Lord God, euen the God of Israel, which onely doeth wonderfull things, and blessed be his glorious Name for euer.

Againe, some doe not onely so abuse Gods glorious Name in their idle and ordinary talke, but also by vaine swearing doe binde, almost euery word with an oath, whereby also they bring Gods heauie iudgements, woes, and curses vpon their owne heads, yea, some cannot speake vnlesse they swrare: It is their Rethoricke, the vulgar poyson of the world, and it is in the mouth of euery
child, for as soone as they can speake, they are able to hurle out any oath, as if they had b√©ene old practicioners. It is an horrible thing to see how this sinne is vsed in all companies, the old man sweareth of custome, the young man in a brauery, the childe by immitation, the Gentleman thinks his sp√©ech not gratious if hee grace it not with gracelesse oathes; the poore man sweareth for necessity, the thiefe to couer his fault, and the strumpet sweareth to deny her sin. A vaine swearer is worse then a thiefe, an harlot, or a slaunderer: the thiefe often stealeth for necessitie, the swearer stealeth Gods glory in a brauery, the harlot sinneth in the darke, the swearer openly: the slaunderer hurts his neighbour, the swearer offends his heauenly Father. The souldier once pearced Christ with a speare. Iohn 19. but swearers with their poysoned tongs breake vp all the wounds of Christ, and tread vnder their f√©et the blood of the couenant they are worse then the Deuill, who trembleth at the name of Christ, but they without feare or reuerence doe most horribly blaspheme it. A man is
knowne of what hart he is by his swearing; for as the Apostle saint Peter was knowne to be of Galile, by his sp√©ech, Mar. 14. 70. so a man (because of the aboundance of the heart the mouth speaketh) may know the children of God, the children of the world, and the children of the Diuell by their sp√©ech. Of the first Dauid speaketh Psal. 84. Blessed are they that dwell in thine house, they will euer praise thee. Of the second sort Iohn saith 3. 31. He that is of the earth is of the earth, and speaketh of the earth. And of the third the Prophet Esay saith, Esay 1. 21, 22. They fret themselues, and curse their Kings, and their gods. As h√©e is an English man that naturally speaketh English, a Spaniard that naturally speaketh Spanish, and a French man that naturally speaketh French: so they that in their vsuall sp√©ech doe praise God, are of God: they that speake most of earthly things, are worldly and carnall men: but they that vse much swearing and cursing, are diuellish, because their sp√©ech is alike. In the auntient Records of the Romans it Iohannes Beetes in preceptorio. is remembred, that a certaine adultresse hauing thr√©e sonnes, tolde her husband,
when she lay on her death bed, that onely one of them was his, but which of them it was, she would not at any hand make knowne. At last, when the time came also that this man should departe the world, he bequeathed to his vnknowen sonne all his lands and goodes, intreating his executors that they would vse all the best meanes they could, to know which of them thr√©e was his naturall sonne: the matter was brought before the Iudge, who calling to minde the wise fact of king Salomon concerning the two women that contended for the liuing childe 1. Reg. 3. thought it good to make experience where Nature rested: and therefore gaue sentence, that the dead body of the father should be bounden vpright to a stake, and that to euery of the thr√©e children should be deliuered a bowe and an arrowe, and each one of them should shoot his arrow at the dead body, with promise, that he which could shoot n√©erest the fathers heart, and pierce deepest into his flesh, should haue land, goodes, and all. The two bastardes (in whome was no sparke of naturall loue) shot earnestly at him, but the third with
reuerence refused to shoot, abhorring to doe so vnnaturall an action, and sharpely reprooued his brethren, for committing so filthy a fact, affirming that hee had rather loose all, then doe as they had done: whereuppon iudgement was giuen that he was the dead mans onely and naturall sonne, and the other two but bastards, and so enioyed his fathers inheritance. Such bastards are they and no true children of God, which in their dayly talke shoote out arrowes of blasphemy at euery part of Christ his sacred body, they cannot beare any naturall loue to Christ that so wound him with oathes, and shoot at his heart, nay, they are Gods enemies. Psal. 139. 20. Thine enemies (O Lord) take thy Name in vaine. As the Salamander which way soeuer he goeth powreth out his poyson, which maketh the herbes to wither; so there are some, who which way soeuer they goe, doe powre out the poyson of their soules. The seruants of Antichrist haue a marke in their right hand, & the Reuel. 13. 16. seruants of the deuill in their tongue: As the godly doe glorifie God, so these dishonour God: What hypocrisie is it

Thirdly, the glorious and fearefull name of the Lord God is vnreuerently abused among the wicked by their false swearing to deceiue, Heb. 6. 16. God hath appointed an oath as an end of all controuersie, and a seale of the truth. But false swearers take the seale of God, & counterfeit it. He that counterfeits the seale of a prince is worthy of death: then what of him that taketh the seale of Gods name to confirme a lye withall? It was a miserable thing that the Iewes required not Iesus, but Barrabas, a thiefe and a murtherer: So periured persons renounce Iesus Christ, & the hope of saluation, the kingdome of God, and all they regard not so much the safgard of
their owne soules, as the fauour of some mortall man, and as Iudas solde Christ for thirty pence, so they renounce Christ Iesus and the kingdome of heauen for a summe of mony, or worldly commodity.

This swearing falsely, to deceiue, is too common a sinne: As the Cretians were saide to be all liars, Tit. 1. 12. so for the most part, among vs, all are swearers, to gaine by it. This is too vsuall a sinne in shoppes, faires, and markets, and I would God no where else. That which is so gotten, hath a fearefull curse vpon it. Maisters will teach their seruants to sweare for gain, and such bring in most profite. 2. Sam. 23. When Dauid lusted for water of the well of Bethlehem, the thr√©e Woorthies brake into the host of the Philistims, in danger of their liues, and drew water out of the well of Bethlehem, and brought it to Dauid, who would not drinke thereof, but powred it out for an offering to the Lord, saying, O Lord, be it farre from me that I should doe this, Is not this the bloud of the men that went in ieoperdie of their liues? Therefore he would not drincke of it. If Dauid would not drinke of the water that was
fetched with danger of those mens liues, wilt thou eate and drinke of that which is gotten with danger of the soule of thy child, seruant, or their owne soule? Let men take h√©ede, swearing falsly to deceiue is but mad sport, whereby mens soules are endangered, but it is so common that it sheweth how few take care for their soules. It would make a mans heart quake to here how the wicked, when they s√©eke to deceiue them with whom they deale, will sweare and take God to witnesse. 1. Samu. 28. Saul going to the witch to deceiue, put on other apparel: So men purposing to deceiue, take on them the name of God as a cloke: Woe to th√©e then whosoeuer thou art, that so takest Gods glorious Name into thy mouth to confirme a lye withall, therby to deceiue thy neighbor, God will make thy plagues wonderfull, great, and fearefull.

Further, I obserue that as the name of God is many wayes vnreuerently abused, so the Lorde will send downe Iudgements, woes, and plagues vpon them in this life, and eternall curses in the life to come, which do not with great
feare and reuerence vse the glorious and fearefull Name of the Lord. Exod. 20. 7. The Lord will not holde him guiltlesse, that taketh his name in vaine. If all the iudges and courts on earth acquit him, God will condemne him. It is a fearefull and venerable name. Ecclus. 23. 11. He that vseth much swearing shall be filled with iniquity, and the plague shall neuer depart from his house. If gun-powder be strawed in an house, there is danger of burning, but when there is a swearer in an house, there is the curse of God more dangerous and ready to take fire then any gun-powder, which will consume the house, and bring it to vtter ruine. Zach. 5. 1, 2. Hag. 2. 11. Ierem. 23. 10. Because of oathes the lande mourneth, swearing euer brings a iudgment with it: The Law and commandement of God by Moses was, Leu. 24. That the swearer should be stoned to death. 2. Reg. 19. 35. One Angel in one night destroyed in the host of Senacherib, one hundred fourescore & fiue thousand men for this sinne of blasphemie. And not onely the iudgements and curses of God belong to this sinne in this life, but also eternall torments in the
life to come except they repent with Zacharie the Prophet foreshewed, Zach. 5. 1, 2, 3. who in a vision from heauen saw a flying booke, the length whereof was twenty cubites, and the breadth of it ten cubites, wherein was written curses against swearers, and that the curses should enter into their houses and consume them with the tymber and stones thereof. You see how great and feareful a flame a blasphemous tongue kindleth, Iam. 3. 5. If then God send downe such wonderful plagues on them which do not with great feare & reuerence vse his dreadful name, then (beloued) it cannot be denied but that this present iudgment of God by plague and pestilence is iustly fallen vpon our English nation: For (alas) how often, and how rashly is that fearefull & glorious Name of God blasphemed among vs? Some thinke there is no grace in their words, if they be not imbossed with damnable oaths, & notwithstanding, who trembleth at it? Nay, who almost reprooueth it? The Iewes rent their garments, Mat. 26. 65. when they heard Gods Name blasphemed, but who among vs sheweth any
token that he is discontented with it? If Pilate an Heathen man, who knewe Iohn 19. 7. not Gods word, was stricken with feare at the hearing of the name of the Sonne of God: No doubt Pilate shall rise vp in iudgement against many among vs, who without all feare and reuerence rende the Name of God in pieces by cursed swearing and blasphemie, and tosse that dreadfull Name of God in their mouthes, as a football is tossed too and fro on the plaine ground. Some maruell to s√©e Lordshippes, houses, and landes translated to strangers from the ancient owners: maruell not at it, there are many houses wherein that fearefull and terrible Name of God is seldome remembred, vnlesse it be to Gods dishonour, and therefore Gods vengeance doeth watch for their destruction, and a secret curse remaineth in their houses; God will make their plagues wonderfull, and the plagues of their seed, till he haue vtterly destroyed them from off the face of the earth: Others wonder to s√©e this man or that suddenly stricken dumbe, and depriued of sp√©ech, euen in time of their health: If thou wonder at
it, glorifie God in thine admiration, for it standeth with Gods iustice that wherein a man sinneth, therein he shall be punished: and therfore as to the rich glutton, Luke 16. who sometime had his choice of drinke and daintie fare, but abused it, a time came (by Gods iust iudgement) when he would haue b√©ene glad of a droppe of water to coole his tongue: So it is a iust thing with God that they which abuse their speech by swearing and cursing (which is a gift that no creature but man hath) should in their life time be depriued of speech, and left dumbe as brute beasts, that others might s√©e & feare, and by their example take heed how they do vnreuerently vse Gods sacred Name. Some againe thinke it strange that God doth at one time threaten vs with sword, at another time punished vs with dearth & famine, and eftsoones with fearefull plague and pestelence, as at this present; but let them thinke it more strange that God doth not rayne fire and brimstone from heauen vpon vs, as he did vpon Sodom and Gomorrah, Gen. 19. or that the earth doeth not swallow vs vp quicke, as it
did Corah and his company, Numb. 16. 32, 33. for our beastly and blasphemous swearing, and vnreuerent trampling of Gods feareful Name vnder our f√©ete. Take h√©ede then whosoeuer thou art, how by thy filthy swearing, thou blowest at the coale of Gods curse, and kindlest the wrath of God as a fire to consume th√©e, and thy posterity; And as thou tenderest the glory of God, the saluation of thy soule, or wouldest haue these present iudgments of God remooued, or taken away from vs, repent th√©e of this and other thy sinnes, that God may command his punishing Angel to stay his hand.

Hitherto you haue heard how God threatneth iudgments, first, against the dissobedient, and secondly, against such as doe not feare that glorious and fearfull Name, The Lord God. Now in the second generall place you shall heare what maner of seruice the Lord requireth for the auoydance of his iudgements, and that is, That we doe not only h√©ere, but also k√©epe and doe all the the words of this Law.

They that would haue the splendent
beames of Gods mercies to shine vpon them, and the woes, curses, and iudgements of God remooued from them, must not onely make an outward shew of hearing the Law of God, but are bound to k√©epe and do all the words of this Law. For manifest proofe of which doctrine, though the Spirit of God sets downe sufficient of this in the 28. of Deuteronomy, and Leutt. 26. yet I Deut. 26. Deut. 28. will adde thereunto that in Esay 1. 19. If you consent and obey, (Hee sayeth not simply, if you heare) you shall eate of the good of the land: But if you refuse and be rebellious, you shall bee deuoured with the sword, for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it. The wicked world in the daies of Noah, no doubt heard him speaking vnto them the truth from God, but because they did not also k√©epe and doe the wordes of Gods Lawe, the iudgement of God fell vpon them by a generall flood. The people of Sodoma often heard Lot, but their hearing was to their further c≈çdemnation, because they did not obserue and doe that they heard. The Iewes, the people of God had Prophets, and good men sent vnto
them, to call them to repentance, yea, Christ Iesus and his Apostles, but what they heard, serued but as a witnesse against them, because they y√©elded not obedience to that they heard, the Iudgements of God fell vpon them in most fearefull maner, and God made their plagues wonderfull, & the plagues of their s√©ede. The wicked and reprobate ones may heare the worde, and talke of the worde, but the k√©eping and doing of it is onely proper to the elect children of God. When the Nineuites repented, It is not sayde, Iona. 3. that God saw or respected their wordes, or outward shew, but their workes. The Iewes had good wordes ynow in their mouthes, though they wanted good workes. Ierem. 7. 4. Templum Domini, templum Domini, the temple of the Lord, the Temple of the Lord, wee haue the temple of the Lord, and we haue Abraham to our father, Matth. 3. 9. when as Matth. 3. 9. they did nothing sutable, but contrary to their wordes, much like many hypocrites now a dayes, who (for the most part) seale vp all their sayings, and daube vp all their doings with an In
trueth, whereas often there is no truth, neither in their wordes nor d√©edes. If words and outward shew would haue serued the turne, then the Pharises had Mat. 6. 5, 16. b√©ene the onely men, for they prayed in the str√©etes, disguised their faces when they fasted, and yet Christ brands them for hypocrites, Mat. 23. and he speakes Mat. 23. 13, 1 ‚Ä¢ 15, 23, 25. to all in generall. Matt. 7. 21. Not euery one that sayeth vnto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdome of heauen, but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heauen. Many good workes shalbe found in hell, but good workes done in faith, goe all to heauen. They shall leaue their hearing and talking behind them, but their practising and walking, and good workes do follow them. Reuel. 14. 13. and therefore the Apostle exhorts vs 1. Pet. 1. to make our election sure by good works. We haue had the Ghospel preached amongst vs now full fourty and eight y√©eres, in more plentifull sort then euer heretofore, but (alas) what effect worketh it among the greatest number? Sin neuer more abounded, the Gospel hath many hearers, but few followers: many talke of it, but few walke after it. Take
h√©ede then of hypocrisie in Gods worshippe and seruice, thou mayest blinde mens eyes with outward shewes of holinesse, but God seeth thine heart. We say, It is ill halting before a cr√©eple, but it is worse dessembling before God. In many places citizens and townsemen desire to haue much preaching, but too few make conscience of practising: Neuer any age wherein there was more s√©eming and lesse being; but take heede, God looketh further into th√©e then all the world besids, not onely into thy words and workes, but also euen into thy heart, whence thy words and workes doe flowe: And at the iudgement God will not giue sentence according to thy outward shewe in hypocrisy, but according to the works which thou hast done. God will not examine th√©e how many sermons thou hast heard, but how much thou hast practised of that thou hast heard, and thy conscience shall answere either for th√©e, or against th√©e. Moreouer, you shall see some hypocrites and dessemblers in Gods worship and seruice, sometimes more zealous in outward profession
then the children of God, talking so godly, and making it so godly as if they were some petty saints dropt downe from heauen, when as indeed, they make no conscience to k√©epe and doe all the wordes of Gods Law. Some of them in outward profession almost as hotte on the spurre as Baals Priests, 1. Reg. 18. 28. who in their blind zeale cut themselues with kniues and launcers, or as the Donatistes, who about 420. y√©eres after Christ, for zeale killed themselues as men not worthy to liue, and so laboured to striue for God, they stroue against God: Such wee haue some who in a blinde zeale runne vp and downe to heare the worde, as if there were a famine of the word in the lande, because (forsooth) they would s√©eme to b√©e more religious then others, but looke into their liues, and 2. Pet. 2. 17. Iude 12. you shall find many hallow tr√©es without fruite, cloudes without water, and caried about with a tempest, to whome the blacke darkenesse is reserued for euer. As Dauid, a man otherwayes zealous for Gods glorie, by his grosse sinnes of adulterie and murther
made the enemies of God to blaspheme, 2. Sam. 12. 13. So the Name of God, and the word of saluation is euill spoken of among the wicked by their meanes which are zealous in profession, but practise nothing, saue that which is naught, and by their bad example, and loosenesse of life many poore soules are endangered of their saluation, for simple men are sooner drawen to God by the good workes that they s√©e, then by the good words that they heare. Looke into the outward face of the Church, especially of the Popish s√©eming Church, and you shall s√©e Ananias renting his clothes, Mar. 14. 63. and taking on with himselfe at the hearing of such wordes as s√©eme to sound like blasphemy or heresy, with an outward zeale of Gods glory, and yet buying a bishoppricke for money, and who will not be bold to doe as such a one doeth? You shall s√©e Herod, Mar. 6. 20. hearing Iohn Baptist preach, and yet make no conscience of adultery nor murther, you shall s√©e the Pharises, vnder a culour of holinesse, Mat. 23. 14. tything mint, and comine, and curious in trifles, and
leaue waightier matters of the Lawe: you shall see some zealous hearers, but m√©ere hypocrites, vsurers, adulterers, slaunderers, backbiters, busie bodies, crafty dealers, dessemblers with God and man, as full of malice, as a toad is full of poyson. It is our duety to talke Deut. 6. 7. of all the words of Gods Law at home and abroad, when we lie downe & when we rise vp, & to heare the word reuerently, because fayth c≈çmeth by hearing, and we must be begotten by the immortall Rom. 10. 17. s√©ede of the word of God: Notwithstanding, they that s√©eme zealous, and are but bare talkers and hearers of the word, without practising and doing all the words of Gods law, are so far from pleasing God, or pacifying his anger when it is once kindled, that they are meanes to increase his vengeance, and to bring downe more fearefull plagues, because God will not be dallyed withall Acts 5. 3, 9. in his worshippe and seruice; and therefore to them, who at the day of Iudgement shal say to Christ, that they Mat. 7. 22, 23. haue prophesied by his Name, and by his Name cast out Deuils, and done many great workes, he shall answere,
I neuer knew you, depart from me ye that worke iniquity: Let then the fruitlesse naked zeale of hypocrites in Gods worshippe and seruice serue as spurres in our sides to pricke vs forward, and make vs earnest to k√©epe and doe all the words of Gods Law, that so God may be glorified in vs, and his feareful iudgments remooued from vs. And let this serue as a looking glasse for all carnall gospellers, and dissembling hypocrites, which deceiue the world with shewes, and themselues with shadowes. Mat. 4. Satan combating with Christ, thought Mat. 4. 3, 6. all sure enough when he had got Scriptures by the end: so many thinke they are halfe way at heauen, if they can get a Bible vnder their arme, and make an outward shew of zeale to here the word, though they shift ouer the practising of it to others, and themselues sl√©epe all the Sermon while: but for all their outward zeale and hearing much, the curse of God shall cleaue vnto them, yea, and the greater shalbe their condemnation, if they doe not also k√©epe and doe all the wordes of Gods Law. 1. Samu. 28. 14. Saul thought that Satan was Samuel,
when he came in likenesse of Samuel; so some thinke that all are Saints, that seeme in the congregation as Saints: But (alas beloued) there is many a Satan in life that seemeth a saint in shew, but maketh no conscience to k√©epe and doe all the wordes of Gods Law. If then we would haue the punishing Angel to hold his hand, and the plagues to cease, wee must not haue Iacobs small voyce, and Esau his rough handes; wee must not be like water-men, who rowe one way, and looke another, talke this way and liue the contrary, curious in other mens liues, and carelesse in our owne: W√©e must not bee like foolish proude Merchants, who make a little showe outward, but haue emptie stoorehouses within: Nor like the Pharisees, who seemed excellent men till Christ vncased them: neither must wee thinke that true Religion consisteth in a talkatiue shew of a mortified profession vnles wee thinke to goe to heauen only in speculation, but we must k√©epe and doe the Law of God, we must be of another temper then hypocrites are: we must not double with God, nor
dissemble in his seruice. Apo. 14. 5. there should be no guile in our mouths; heart, and tongue, and hand should goe together, Psalm. 45. The Kings daughter is all glorious within. Esay exhorting the people to true repentance for the auoyding of Gods iudgements sayth not, Learne to speake well, to heare much, or to hide a wolfe in a sh√©epes skinne, or learne to cloke a bad life vnder a good profession: but hee sayeth, Esay 1. 17. Learne to doe well, apply your selues to equity. It was our Sauiours rule, Iohn 10. 25. The workes that I doe, shall testifie of mee. And this should be a rule for euery member of Christ, By their workes you shal know them.

Againe, as it is our duety (for the auoyding of Gods iudgements) not only to here, but also to obserue and do the words of Gods Law: So further the Lord requireth the performing and k√©eping not of this, or that part, but of All the words of this Law. Iam. 2. 10. Whosoeuer shall keepe the whole Law, and yet faileth in one point, he is guiltie of all. Let vs then Clense our selues, 2. Cor. 7. 1. from all filthinesse of the flesh and spirit, and growe vp vnto full holinesse in the feare of God.
For wee must bee clensed within and without. 1. Pet. 1. 15. As he which hath called you is holly, so be ye holly in all maner of conuersation. God giueth no man libertie to sinne in the least degr√©e, the reasons hereof are. First, because all sin fighteth against the soule. 1. Pet. 2. 11. I beseech you as pilgrims and strangers abstain from fleshly lusts, which fight against the soule. Euery sinne fighteth against the soule, and therefore we must abstaine from all sinne, and not sinne in the least degr√©e. Secondly, because sinne maketh a separation betw√©ene God and vs. Esay 59. 2. Your iniquities haue separated betweene you and your God, and your sinnes haue hid his face from you, that he will not heare. Iere. 5. 25. Your iniquities haue turned away these things, and your sinnes haue hindred good things from you. Thirdly, because euery sinne doth purchase Gods wrath. Psal. 5. 4, 5. For thou art not a God that loueth wickednesse, neither shall euill dwell with thee. The foolish shall not stand in thy sight, for thou hatest all them that worke iniquity Rom. 1. 18. The wrath of God is reueiled from heauen against al vnrighteousnes and vngodlinesse of men, which
withhold the truth in righteousnes. Our sins do bring down Gods wrath and iudgements by famine, sword, plague, & pestilence and therefore if we would be deliuered from these iudgments which lately in fearefull manner lye vpon vs, we must make conscience to k√©epe and doe All the words of Gods Law. This doctrine also serueth to reproue them that are carelesse in sin, and make no bones to commit sinne euen with gr√©edinesse, we should pul such as it were out of the fire. Iud. 23. For sin is as dangerous to the soule as fire is to the body. Moreouer, we should auoyd all occasions of sin, and vse all good meanes to k√©epe vs vndefiled therwith, to frequent good company, and auoyd badde, for if we be carefull to shunne such places and persons as are infected with the plague, and to vse all preseruatiues against it, then much more against sinne, which is the plague and poyson of the soule. Lastly, this serueth to condemne the sinfull shifting which some vse to make from one sinne to another: I haue b√©ene an adulterer (will some man say) but I thanke God, I haue left that sinne, and now I am
but a little couetous, &c. But as one poyson is enough to destroy the bodie, so one sinne is sufficient to condemne the soule. We must not doe as Saul did, who being sent to destroy all the Amalekites. 1. Sam. 15. 3, 9. spared their King Agag, and the better sh√©epe and oxen, and the fat beasts, and the lambes, and all that was good, that they would not destroy, but all that was vile and nought worth, that they destroyed: So we must not thinke it sufficient to cast away one sinne, or a few sinnes, but we must destroy our fatte sinnes, our profitable sinnes, our pleasant sinnes, and all. If we would haue our land clensed from infection of plague and pestilence, we must labour to clense our selues, first, from all filthinesse of flesh and Spirit, we must k√©epe and doe not this or that 1. Cor. 7. 1. part, but all the words of Gods Lawe. God giueth no man libertie to commit the least sin: and therefore as we would haue all parts glorified, so we must also first haue all parts sanctified, &c.

div.head: The second Sermon.
div.p: YOU haue heard in the former sermon. First against whome the Lord here threatneth plagues, and Iudgements, viz. the disobedient, and them that feare not his glorious Name. And secondly, what maner of seruice he requireth, for auoyding of his Iudgements, namely, not onely the hearing, but also the keeping and doing of his Law, and that not of this or that part of it, but of all the words of his Law.

Now commeth the third general part to bee handled, which doth shewe the cause of the iudgements of God threatned, and now fallen vpon vs, & that is, sin, or the not k√©eping and doing of al the wordes of Gods Law. But first let me answere one obiection which may hence arise. Some man may say, Why doeth
God threaten temporall plagues and punishments in this life, and eternall torments in the life to come against those that doe not obserue and doe all the words of his Law, whereas (Christ onely excepted) no man can, nor euer did performe and doe the whole law so perfectly and absolutly as God requireth at our hands? To this I answere: The Lord requireth nothing but what we are bounden to doe, and that wee might haue done had not Adam sinned: And therefore considering the corruption of our nature, we ought to acknowledge our frailtie, and to call vpon God by faithful prayer, that he would vouchsafe by his holy Spirit to direct vs how to frame our liues according to his Law, and accept of vs in Christ and for his sake, who hath fulfilled the Law for vs. And although the best Saints of God be farre short of that perfection which the Lord requireth, yet let it bee our comfort that the Lord accepteth of our willingnesse, and desire to doe that he commandeth: So he accepted of Abraham, Gen. 22. 10. And so also will hee Gen. 22. 10, 11 12. accept of all Abrahams children: For
though Abraham did not sacrifice his son yet his willingnesse to haue done it at Gods commandement, was accepted as if he had done it: So if thou haue a willing minde, and vnfained desire to k√©epe and doe all the wordes of Gods Lawe, though thou come much too short of it, yet the Lord will accept of thy willing mind & vnfained desire to do it, as if thou haddest done it. Nehem. 1. 11. But will Nehem. 1. 11. a willing minde & vnfained desire serue the turne? Yes, If thou labour to walke in the feare of God, and desirest more faith, when thou hast not so much as thou wouldest haue: If, I say, thou desirest in thine heart, not to offend God, f√©elest wants in thy selfe, thirstest to doe better, & f√©elest an inward griefe ye thou canst do no better, thy willing mind being aboue thine hability, doubtlesse God doth accept of th√©e as if thou hadest kept and done al ye words of his Law. 2. Cor. 2. Cor. 8. 2, 12. 8. If first there be a willing mind, it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that he hath not. If a father willing to prooue the obedience of his child, should bid him goe, & fetch such a great ston, which he knew wel enough he were
not able to mooue, much lesse to carie, the child should goe and strugle with it, and finding that he could not by any meanes doe it, should returne to his father, and tell him, Father, I haue done what I am able, and vsed all my strength, but it will not be: What father is it, that will not accept of his chiids willing minde and endeuour, as if he had done it? So our heauenly Father accepteth of our willing and obedient mindes, though we be not able to k√©epe and doe all the words of his Law.

But to our purpose, What is the cause of Gods iudgements? Sinne, for it doeth kindle the wrath of God as a fire, and brings down his iudgements. Lam. 3. 39. Man suffereth for his sin. Psal.
Lam. 3. 39. Psal. 107. 34. 107. 34. A fruitfull land maketh he barren, Why? for the wickednesse of them that dwell therein. Yea, sinne is so filthy a thing before God, that it is said to defile the earth. Gene. 6. 12. God looked vpon the earth, and behold, It was corrupt, for all
Gen. 6. 12. 1. Reg. 8. 35. flesh had corrupt his way vpon the earth. 2. Pet. 2. God created the Angels in singular 2. Pet. 1. 4. perfection, yet when they committed sinne against God, all his loue was turned
vengeance, he cast them downe into hell, and deliuered them into chaines of darknesse to be kept vnto damnation. Gen. 1‚ñ™ 26. God created Adam and Heuah,
Gen. 1. 26, 27 placed them in paradise, subiected all creatures vnto them, ioyned them in mariage, blessed them, and performed all tokenes of loue vnto them; Adam commited but one sinne, and that by his wiues procurement, no sooner had he done it, but frendship was broken betw√©ene God and him, God cursed him, and cast him out of Paradise. Num. 20. Num. 20. 12, 24. Moses and Aaron men highly in Gods fauour, yet when as at the wildernesse of sinne they doubted of the miracle promised by God, though they repented, yet God answered them, Because you haue dishonoured me before the people, and not beleeued me, to sanctifie me in the presence of the children of Israel, therefore you shall not bring this people into the land which I haue giuen them. 2. Sam. 11. Dauid a 2. Sam. 11. 4. man after Gods owne heart committed adultery, but what came of it? though he bewayled and repented his sinne all the dayes of his life after, with many a sigh and bitter teare: yet notwithstanding,
as he had brought shame vpon an other mans wife, so he saw shame vpon his own children while he liued: Ammon, one of his sonnes, c≈çmitted incest with his owne sister Thamar. 2. Sam. 13. 28. Absolon and other of Dauids sonnes killed 2. Sam. 13. 1, 14. 2. Sam. 13. 28, 29, 32. his brother, Ammon for that filthie facte. The same Absolon, not long after droue his father Dauid out of his kingdome, and most impudently laie with his fathers wiues, whereupon 2. Sam. 15. 7, 8. 2. Sam. 16. 21. followed horrible slaughter among the people, and sharpe battell, wherein Absolon, and many thousands moe were slaine.

If God so punished his d√©erest children in this life for sinne, what haue we deserued which doe multiplie our transgressions, and heape one sinne vppon another, how can it bee but God must n√©edes make our plagues wonderfull? Nay; sinne doth not onely bring Gods iudgements in generall, but also more particularlie, it is the cause of plague, pestilence, sickenesses and bodilie diseases. Ierem. 21. 6. For Iere. 21. 6. sinne (saith the Lord) I will smite the inhabitants of Ierusalem, and man and beast
Exod. 9. 10.
shall die of a great pestilence. Exodus 9. God brought vpon Egypt botch, blayne, boile, and grieuous diseases vpon the people for their crueltie towards the Leuit. 26. 25. Israelites, and contempt of the Prophets. Leuiticus 26. 25. The Lorde threatneth the sworde, sickenesse, and 2. Reg. 5. 27. pestilence vpon the people for their sins. 2. Reg. 5. 27. Gehesie was plagued with the leprosie of Naaman the Syrian, Psal. 38. 3. for his couetousnesse and bribery. Psal. 38. 3. Dauid confesseth that Gods hand was heauie vpon him for his sinne, and that hee had no rest in his bones by reason of his iniquities. Iohn 5. 14. Christ hauing healed him that Ioh. 5. 14. was diseased thirtie and eight yeeres willed him to sinne no more, least a worse thing happened vnto him: Signifying, that the cause of his sickenesse was his sinne. Let vs not impute this present heauie Iudgement of God vpon vs to any secondarie causes, but let vs acknowledge our sinnes to bee the cause of it. Let vs say with Iosephs brethren, Genesis
Gen. 42. 21, ‚Ä¢ 2 42. 21. Wee haue sinned, and therefore this trouble is come vppon vs. And let
euery one looke into himselfe, and say, as Micha. 7. 9. It is my sinne that hath procured
Micah 7. 9. this. Some say, It is Londons sinnes that hath brought this iudgement vpon them and vs: I say, not they onely, but we as well as they haue sinned, and deserued this and worse then this, and except we repent we shall all likewise perish. There is no sect nor sort of people Luc. 13. 2. can excuse themselues: Looke amongst men of worth and wealth, and you shal find many of them contemners of the word, giuen to oppression, prodigalitie. 2. not threaten to bring these iudgements vpon strangers, and reprobates, but vpon his owne people. I will (saith hee) make Thy plagues wonderfull. God hath in all ages bene sharpe with his owne people. Consider how hee dealt with the Iewes from time to time, till at last he dispersed them: He suffered them to be in bondage, and slauery in Egypt: when he brought them thence, he punished them in the wildernesse: afterwards in Iosuah his time, how did God giue them ouer to the vncircumcised, and so continued afflicting them, till at last he brake off his couenƒÅt with them? He threatned sword, famine, and pestilence against them, and performed it. Neuer any people tasted more plenteously of outward afflictions then the Iewes. Exod. 12. 37. Sixe hundred thousand of them, besides children came out Exod. 12. 37. of Egypt: but for their sinnes God made hauocke of them: within the citie of Ierusalem in fourteene moneths space the sword, famine, and pestilence consumed eleuen hundred thousand of them, and so lamemtable was their state, that the very enemie entring the citie, pitied
them, and commaunded that no man should be slaine, but that they should be sold, thirtie for a peny, as they had sold Christ before for thirtie pence: So that being once the people of God, they are now no people, yea, the very name of a Iew is become odious, and therefore the Prophet in the person of Ierusalem complayned, Lam. 1. 12. Was euer any sorrow
Lam. 1. 12. like mine? The reasons why God doeth thus afflict his owne people are many. First, the people of God are tyed to obedience, and to glorifie Gods Name; but when they sinne, they make his glory and Name to be blasphemed, and their profession to be dishonoured, and therefore God punisheth them more grieuously. 2. Sam. 12. 14. So Dauid by 2. Sam. 12. 14. his sinne made the enemies of God to blaspheme. Rom. 2. 24. The Iewes are reprooued Ro. m 2. 24. for not k√©eping the Lawe, The Name of God (saith the Apostle) is blasphemed among the Gentiles through you: And this also is one speciall cause wherfore the Lord thus punisheth vs, we are now Gods people, bounden so obedience as were the Iewes, but (alas) many among vs dishonour their profession,
and by their badde conuersation make the Gospell to bee blasphemed, and ill spoken of, and therefore he executeth his iudgements vpon vs.

A second reason wherefore God so afflicteth his deerest children is, that as he aduaunceth them highest by his mercies, so if they abuse, or contemne them, it is right that he should cast them down to greatest miseries. So Capernaum
Mat. 11. 23. which was lifted vp to heauen (because it had the preaching of the word, and miracles) was brought downe to hell, by corporall punishment. And the seauen Churches in Asia, and those to Reuel. 1. 4. whom Saint Paul writte his Epistles, once had the glorious light of the Gospell, but for their contempt and disobedience their candelsticke was remoued. Neuer nation vnder heauen tasted more plenteously of Gods mercies then we, God hath exalted vs to heauen, by the preaching of his Gospell: but if we continue to abuse his great and many blessinges vpon vs, let vs take h√©ed lest in his Iustice he cast vs downe into an hell of miseries. For if God haue so aflicted his d√©erest children, and his own
people, how can wee promise impunitie to our selues, or perswade our selues that because wee are his people, wee haue the word preached, and Sacraments (according to Christs Institution) administred, therefore hee will not punish vs? And let the fearefull example of Elie serue as a looking-glasse to all parentes, not to bolster their children in any bad actions, but sharpely to corect them. sinne in his owne people, and deerest seruants: so doe thou hate sinne, and condemne it, both in thy self and others. He hateth sinne so much, that if thou were as the signet of his fingar, hee would plucke th√©e off, if thou sin against him. A godly father will not beare with his childe in wickednesse, because hee loueth him: the husband will not smother vp his wiues faultes, but by gentle perswasions, or (if that will not serue) with sharpe reprehensions reproue her, because he loueth her: So God oft times aflicteth his children because he loueth them.

Thirdly, whereas God doeth for the most parte, sharpely correct his owne people in this life, we ought not rashely to iudge, nor condemne those that are here most subiect to crosses and aflictions, If we s√©e Gods hand extraordinarily heauie vpon any man, let vs not therefore giue sentence vpon him that he is a badde man, or a reprobate: So Iobs frendes dealt with him, when they sawe his strong aflictions, they inferred that hee was an hypocrite, and God Iob 8. 13. Iobs afflictions none troubled him more then this. So Christ was accounted a badde man because hee had many Esay 53. 3. troubles: Whereas hee was without any spot of sinne, neither was there any guile found in his mouth. Let vs not then iudge hardly of those that are afflicted, because God will so trie his deerest children; and by many tribulations we must enter into eternall Ioy: We may not looke to goe to heauen on a fether-bedde, but if wee see a notorious badde man afflicted, then we may say, such a man is punished for his sinnes.

Lastly, I note that God doeth here threaten to punish disobedience and prophanation of his name euen in a mans posterity. I will make (sayth hee) thy plagues wonderfull, and the plagues of thy seede. The Iewes for their disobedience and contempt of Gods Lawe, did not onely feele and finde in themselues the iudgements of God, but also their posterity smarted for it: It was the cause of the ouerthrowe of Ierusalem, and that so many thousands (as I haue shewed you) perished therewith
sword, famine, plague, and pestilence: It was the cause of the Iewes captiuitie, and that their seede and posteritte are made vagabonds vpon the earth. Genes. 9. 25. Cham did no more but discouer the priuie parts of his father, Gen. 9. 25. but for his so doing, hee was not onely accursed, but also of a free childe became a bound seruant for euer, both in himselfe, and also in his posterity. The last part sheweth vs the author of these plagues, namely, The Lord. Then the Lord will make thy plagues wonderfull. Prophane and ignorant men thinke that the plague commeth by the infection of the ayre, and that they are safe enough if they come not into such places as are infected. But the Spirit of God here teacheth vs that God is the author of all plagues and afflictions, he punisheth where he will, and whom he will: they beginne, continue, and increase by his appointment, neither doe they cease (though man and Angels do what they can) till the punishing Angel, by Gods appoyntment stay his hand.
